qas.question: Plants lack what kind of immune cells?
Plant cells respond to the molecules associated with pathogens known as what?
Cells of the site of an infection in a plant undergo what process to prevent spread of the disease?
What is a kind of defense response that makes the entire plant resistant to a particular agent?
What is a mechanism that can help plants block virus replication?
What cells do plants and animals both have?
What happens when all parts of a plant become infected?
What do cells away from the site of the infection undergo?

plausible_answers.text: cells at the site of infection

context: Unlike animals, plants lack <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>phagocytic<a0_1/> cells<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_0/>, but many plant immune responses involve systemic chemical signals that are sent through a plant. Individual plant cells respond to molecules associated with pathogens known as <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>Pathogen-associated molecular patterns<a1_1/><a1_0/> or PAMPs<a1_2/>. When a part of a plant becomes infected, the plant produces a <b6_0>localized hypersensitive response<b6_0/>, whereby <b8_0>cells at the site of infection<b8_0/> undergo <a2_2><b7_0>rapid <a2_0><a2_1>apoptosis<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> to prevent the spread of the disease to other parts of the plant. <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>Systemic acquired resistance<a3_1/> (SAR)<a3_2/><a3_0/> is a type of defensive response used by plants that renders the entire plant resistant to a particular infectious agent. <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b9_0>RNA silencing mechanisms<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> are particularly important in this systemic response as they can block virus replication.
